Authors: Willemé, P; Dumont, M
Author Full Names: Willeme, Peter; Dumont, Michel
Article Title: Machines that Go Ping': Medical Technology and Health Expenditures in OECD Countries
Author Keywords: health care expenditures; income elasticity; aging; obesity; medical technology
Keywords Plus: CARE EXPENDITURE; DETERMINANTS; INSURANCE; INCOME; POPULATION; GROWTH; INDEX; COSTS; TESTS
Abstract: Technology is believed to be a major determinant of increasing health spending. The main difficulty to quantify its effect is to find suitable proxies to measure medical technological innovation. This paper's main contribution is the use of data on approved medical devices and drugs to proxy for medical technology. The effects of these variables on total real per capita health spending are estimated using a panel model for 18 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries covering the period 1981-2012. The results confirm the substantial cost-increasing effect of medical technology, which accounts for almost 50% of the explained historical growth of spending. Despite the overall net positive effect of technology, the effect of two subgroups of approvals on expenditure is significantly negative. These subgroups can be thought of as representing incremental medical innovation', whereas the positive effects are related to radically innovative pharmaceutical products and devices. A separate time series model was estimated for the USA because the FDA approval data in fact only apply to the USA, while they serve as proxies for the other OECD countries. Our empirical model includes an indicator of obesity, and estimations confirm the substantial contribution of this lifestyle variable to health spending growth in the countries studied. Authors: Breitung, J; Demetrescu, M
Author Full Names: Breitung, Joerg; Demetrescu, Matei
Article Title: Instrumental variable and variable addition based inference in predictive regressions
Author Keywords: Causality test; Persistence; Integration; Long memory; IV estimation
Keywords Plus: TIME-SERIES REGRESSION; LIMIT THEORY; MODELS; TESTS; ESTIMATORS; ORDER
Abstract: Valid inference in predictive regressions depends in a crucial manner on the degree of persistence of the predictor variables. The paper studies test procedures that are robust in the sense that their asymptotic null distributions are invariant to the persistence of the predictor, that is, the limiting distribution is the same irrespective of whether the regressors are stationary or (nearly) integrated. Existing procedures are often conservative (e.g. tests based on Bonferroni bounds), are based on highly restrictive assumptions (such as homoskedasticity or assuming an AR(1) process for the regressor) or fail to have power against alternatives in a 1/T neighborhood of the null hypothesis. We first propose a refinement of the variable addition method with improved asymptotic power approaching the optimal rate. Second, inference based on instrumental variables may further improve the (local) power of the test and even achieve local power under the optimal 1/T rate. We give high-level conditions under which the suggested variable addition and instrumental variable procedures are valid no matter whether the predictor is stationary, near-integrated or integrated, or exhibits time-varying volatility. All test statistics possess a standard limiting distribution. Monte Carlo experiments suggest that tests based on simple combinations of instruments perform most promising relative to existing tests. An application to quarterly US stock returns illustrates the need for robust inference. (C) 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Cotti, C; Dunn, RA; Tefft, N
Author Full Names: Cotti, Chad; Dunn, Richard A.; Tefft, Nathan
Article Title: The Dow is Killing Me: Risky Health Behaviors and the Stock Market
Author Keywords: stock market; risky health behaviors; business cycle; alcohol; cigarettes
Keywords Plus: ECONOMIC-CONDITIONS; ALCOHOL-PROBLEMS; MORTALITY-RATES; UNITED-STATES; RECESSIONS; UNEMPLOYMENT; FATALITIES; DRINKING; VEHICLE; TIMES
Abstract: We investigate how risky health behaviors and self-reported health vary with the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) and during stock market crashes. Because stock market indices are leading indicators of economic performance, this research contributes to our understanding of the macroeconomic determinants of health. Existing studies typically rely on the unemployment rate to proxy for economic performance, but this measure captures only one of many channels through which the economic environment may influence individual health decisions. We find that large, negative monthly DJIA returns, decreases in the level of the DJIA, and stock market crashes are widely associated with worsening self-reported mental health and more cigarette smoking, binge drinking, and fatal car accidents involving alcohol. These results are consistent with predictions from rational addiction models and have implications for research on the association between consumption and stock prices. Authors: Kim, M; Yoo, BK
Author Full Names: Kim, Minchul; Yoo, Byung-Kwang
Article Title: Cost-Effectiveness Analysis of a Television Campaign to Promote Seasonal Influenza Vaccination Among the Elderly
Author Keywords: cost-effectiveness; elderly population; influenza vaccination; television campaign
Keywords Plus: UNITED-STATES; DISPARITIES; MEDIA; COVERAGE; RATES; PREVENTION; ETHNICITY; VACCINES; LANGUAGE; OLDER
Abstract: Background: The U.S. policy goals regarding influenza vaccination coverage rate among the elderly include the increase in the coverage rate and the elimination of disparities across racial/ethnic groups. Objective: To examine the potential effectiveness of a television (TV) campaign to increase seasonal influenza vaccination among the elderly. Methods: We estimated the incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER, defined as incremental cost per additionally vaccinated Medicare individual) of a hypothetical nationwide TV campaign for influenza vaccination compared with no campaign. We measured the effectiveness of the nationwide TV campaign (advertised once a week at prime time for 30 seconds) during a 17-week influenza vaccination season among four racial/ethnic elderly groups (N=39 million): non Hispanic white (W), non-Hispanic African American (AA), English-speaking Hispanic (EH), and Spanish-speaking Hispanic (SH). Results: The hypothetical campaign cost was $5,960,000 (in 2012 US dollars). The estimated campaign effectiveness ranged from -1.1% (the SH group) to 1.42% (the W group), leading to an increased disparity in influenza vaccination among non-Hispanic white and non-Hispanic African American (W-AA) groups (0.6 percentage points), W-EH groups (0.1 percentage points), and W-SH groups (1.5 percentage points). The estimated ICER was $23.54 (95% confidence interval $14.21-$39.37) per additionally vaccinated Medicare elderly in a probabilistic analysis. Race/ethnicity-specific ICERs were lowest among the EH group ($22.27), followed by the W group ($22.47) and the AA group ($30.55). The nationwide TV campaign was concluded to be reasonably cost-effective compared with a benchmark intervention (with ICER $44.39 per vaccinated individual) of a school-located vaccination program. Break-even analyses estimated the maximum acceptable campaign cost to be $14,870,000, which was comparable to the benchmark ICER. Conclusions: The results could justify public expenditures on the implementation of a future nationwide TV campaign, which should include multilingual campaigns, for promoting seasonal influenza vaccination. 2015 (C) Published by Elsevier Inc. on behalf of International Society for Pharmacoeconomics and Outcomes Research (ISPOR).

Authors: Larrea, C; Ruiz, L
Author Full Names: Larrea, C.; Ruiz, L.
Article Title: Simple coalitional strategy profiles in repeated games
Keywords Plus: EQUILIBRIA
Abstract: In this paper we introduce simple coalitional strategy profiles to avoid group deviations in repeated games. In the repeated Cournot supergame we prove that it is possible to sustain the symmetric monopoly outcome by means of a variety of strategies which satisfy the requirement that no coalition (other than the grand one) will deviate in any subgame. Authors: Lorenz, N
Author Full Names: Lorenz, Normann
Article Title: The interaction of direct and indirect risk selection
Author Keywords: Risk selection; Risk adjustment; Health insurance; Discrete choice; Imperfect competition
Keywords Plus: ADVERSE SELECTION; HEALTH-CARE; ADJUSTMENT; PREMIUMS; MARKETS
Abstract: This paper analyzes the interaction of direct and indirect risk selection in health insurance markets. It is shown that direct risk selection - using measures unrelated to the benefit package like selective advertising or 'losing' applications of high risk individuals - nevertheless has an influence on the distortions of the benefit package caused by indirect risk selection. Direct risk selection (DRS) may either increase or decrease these distortions, depending on the type of equilibrium (pooling or separating), the type of DRS (positive or negative)-and the type of cost for DRS (individual-specific or not). Regulators who succeed in reducing DRS by, e.g., banning excessive advertising or implementing fines for 'losing' applications, may therefore (imintendedly) mitigate or exacerbate the distortions of the benefit package caused by indirect risk selection. It is shown that the interaction of direct and indirect risk selection also alters the formula for optimal risk adjustment. (C) 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Borden, WB; Chiang, YP; Kronick, R
Author Full Names: Borden, William B.; Chiang, Yen-Pin; Kronick, Richard
Article Title: Bringing Patient-Centered Outcomes Research to Life
Author Keywords: dissemination; health care delivery; implementation; patient-centered outcomes research
Keywords Plus: SERIOUS CARDIOVASCULAR EVENTS; ADULTS; YOUNG
Abstract: A substantial gap exists between medical evidence that is known and medical evidence that is put into practice. Although the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) has a long history of developing the content of evidence, the agency now pivots to close that gap by focusing on evidence dissemination and implementation. Achieving better health outcomes requires both the generation of new patient-centered outcomes research (PCOR) knowledge and the appropriate and timely implementation of that knowledge into practice. The Affordable Care Act provided funds to support both types of PCOR efforts, with AHRQ building on years of experience to advance research dissemination and implementation. This article describes the work the AHRQ has done, is doing, and will do in the future. To communicate PCOR evidence findings, AHRQ is currently synthesizing research findings into convincing collections of evidence that can be best taken up by clinicians, patients and caregivers, and policymakers. The future direction for AHRQ is to improve the context for evidence and practice improvement, thereby creating an environment receptive to PCOR. Toward this goal, AHRQ is actively engaging partners, such as professional societies and insurers, to make evidence central to decision making. In addition, AHRQ recently launched two programs that seek to both understand and encourage the use of evidence in clinical practice. Throughout these efforts, AHRQ will continually assess needs and adapt initiatives to ensure that PCOR translates into improved patient-centered health outcomes.

Authors: Craig, BM; Brown, DS; Reeve, BB
Author Full Names: Craig, Benjamin M.; Brown, Derek S.; Reeve, Bryce B.
Article Title: The Value Adults Place on Child Health and Functional Status
Author Keywords: National Survey of Children with Special Health Care Needs; NS-CSHCN; paired comparisons; patient-reported outcomes; QALY; quality adjusted life years
Keywords Plus: FAMILY-CENTERED CARE; PARENT PREFERENCES; NATIONAL-SURVEY; UTILITY SCORES; MEDICAL HOME; NEEDS; IMPACT; DISPARITIES; VALUATION; INSURANCE
Abstract: Objectives: To summarize the value adults place on child health and functional status and provide a new quantitative tool that enhances our understanding of the benefits of new health technologies and illustrates the potential contributions of existing data sets for comparative effectiveness research in pediatrics. Methods: Respondents, ages 18 years and older, were recruited from a nationally representative panel between August 2012 and February 2013 to complete an online survey. The survey included a series of paired comparisons that asked respondents to choose between child health and functional status outcomes, which were described using the National Survey of Children with Special Health Care Needs, a 14-item descriptive system of child health outcomes. Using respondent choices regarding an unnamed 7- or 10-year-old child, generalized linear model analyses estimated the value of child health and functional status on a quality-adjusted life-year scale. Results: Across the domains of health and functional status, repeated or chronic physical pain, feeling anxious or depressed, and behavioral problems (such as acting out, fighting, bullying, or arguing) were most valuable, as indicated by adult respondents' preference of other health problems to avoid outcomes along these domains. Discussion: These findings may inform comparative effectiveness research, health technology assessments, clinical practice guidelines, and public resource allocation decisions by enhancing understanding of the value adults place on the health and functional status of children. Conclusions: Improved measurement of public priorities can promote national child health by drawing attention to what adults value most and complementing conventional measures of public health surveillance.

Authors: Robinson, PM; Velasco, C
Author Full Names: Robinson, Peter M.; Velasco, Carlos
Article Title: Efficient inference on fractionally integrated panel data models with fixed effects
Author Keywords: Panel data; Fractional time series; Estimation; Testing; Bias correction
Keywords Plus: MAXIMUM-LIKELIHOOD-ESTIMATION; TIME-SERIES
Abstract: A dynamic panel data model is considered that contains possibly stochastic individual components and a common stochastic time trend that allows for stationary and nonstationary long memory and general parametric short memory. We propose four different ways of coping with the individual effects so as to estimate the parameters. Like models with autoregressive dynamics, ours nests 1(1) behaviour, but unlike the nonstandard asymptotics in the autoregressive case, estimates of the fractional parameter can be asymptotically normal. For three of the estimates, establishing this property is made difficult due to bias caused by the individual effects, or by the consequences of eliminating them, which appears in the central limit theorem except under stringent conditions on the growth of the cross-sectional size N relative to the time series length T, though in case of two estimates these can be relaxed by bias correction, where the biases depend only on the parameters describing autocorrelation. For the fourth estimate, there is no bias problem, and no restrictions on N. Implications for hypothesis testing and interval estimation are discussed, with central limit theorems for feasibly bias-corrected estimates included. A Monte Carlo study of finite-sample performance is included. (C) 2015 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.

Authors: Janssens, A; Rogers, M; Coon, JT; Allen, K; Green, C; Jenkinson, C; Tennant, A; Logan, S; Morris, C
Author Full Names: Janssens, Astrid; Rogers, Morwenna; Coon, Jo Thompson; Allen, Karen; Green, Colin; Jenkinson, Crispin; Tennant, Alan; Logan, Stuart; Morris, Christopher
Article Title: A Systematic Review of Generic Multidimensional Patient-Reported Outcome Measures for Children, Part II: Evaluation of Psychometric Performance of English-Language Versions in a General Population
Author Keywords: children and young people; measurement properties; patient-reported outcomes; review
Keywords Plus: QUALITY-OF-LIFE; HEALTH-STATUS MEASUREMENT; CROSS-CULTURAL SURVEY; SELF-REPORT; METHODOLOGICAL QUALITY; FUNCTIONAL STATUS; ILLNESS-PROFILE; AGE SUBGROUPS; CORE SCALES; REPORT FORM
Abstract: Objectives: The objectives of this systematic review were 1) to identify studies that assess the psychometric performance of the English-language version of 35 generic multidimensional patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) for children and young people in general populations and evaluate their quality and 2) to summarize the psychometric properties of each PROM. Methods: MEDLINE, EMBASE, and PsyclNFO were searched. The methodological quality of the articles was assessed using the COnsensus-based Standards for selection of health Measurement INstruments checklist. For each PROM, extracted evidence of content validity, construct validity, internal consistency, test retest reliability, proxy reliability, responsiveness, and precision was judged against standardized reference criteria. Results: We found no evidence for 14 PROMs. For the remaining 21 PROMs, 90 studies were identified. The methodological quality of most studies was fair. Quality was generally rated higher in more recent studies. Not reporting how missing data were handled was the most common reason for downgrading the quality. None of the 21 PROMs has had all psychometric properties evaluated; data on construct validity and internal consistency were most frequently reported. Conclusions: Overall, consistent positive findings for at least five psychometric properties were found for Child Health and Illness Profile, Healthy Pathways, KIDSCREEN, and Multi-dimensional Student Life Satisfaction Scale. None of the PROMs had been evaluated for responsiveness to detect change in general populations. Further welldesigned studies with transparent reporting of methods and results are required.

Authors: Karpov, A
Author Full Names: Karpov, Alexander
Article Title: Alliance incentives under the D'Hondt method
Keywords Plus: PROPORTIONAL REPRESENTATION; ELECTORAL SYSTEMS; APPORTIONMENT; ELECTION
Abstract: This paper studies the incentives for alliance (coalition) formation. It provides an example of an alliance that leads to unlimited seat gains. A full description of a set that guarantees the lack of successful alliance is found. The probability of the lack of successful alliances is evaluated. A game-theoretical approach for alliance formation is applied. (C) 2014 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Zhong, Y; Lin, PJ; Cohen, JT; Winn, AN; Neumann, PJ
Author Full Names: Zhong, Yue; Lin, Pei-Jung; Cohen, Joshua T.; Winn, Aaron N.; Neumann, Peter J.
Article Title: Cost-Utility Analyses in Diabetes: A Systematic Review and Implications from Real-World Evidence
Author Keywords: cost-utility analysis; diabetes; health care utilization; systematic review
Keywords Plus: REPAGLINIDE PLUS METFORMIN; CLINICAL-PRACTICE; ECONOMIC-ANALYSIS; MEDICAL LITERATURE; USERS GUIDES; INTERVENTIONS; GUIDELINES; MELLITUS; GLARGINE; ARTICLE
Abstract: Objectives: To systematically review the cost-effectiveness of diabetes interventions, identify high value diabetes services, and estimate potential gains from increasing their utilization. Methods: The study consisted of two steps. First, we reviewed cost-utility analyses (CUAs) related to diabetes published through the end of 2012, using the Tufts Medical Center Cost-Effectiveness Analysis Registry (w.cearegistry. c)r.O. We used logistic regression to examine factors independently associated with favorable cost-effective ratios. Second, we used the Humedica electronic medical records to estimate potential savings and health benefits gained by shifting patients currently receiving low-value services to high-value alternatives. Results: We identified 196 diabetes CUAs, of which 55% examined pharmaceuticals. Most (70%) diabetes CUAs focused on treatment rather than prevention. Most used a health care payer perspective and were industrysponsored. Of the 497 published cost utility ratios, 82% examined an intervention recommended by diabetes guidelines. Approximately 73% of the interventions were cost-saving or below $50,000 per quality-adjusted life-year. Logistic regression analysis showed that higher quality CUAs, CUAs conducted from the US perspective, surgical interventions, and guideline-recommended interventions were more likely to report favorable ratios. Of the 7907 eligible patients with diabetes in our sample, up to 7117 could in principle be shifted to cost-saving treatments, reducing costs by $12.5 million and gaining more than 1938 quality-adjusted life-years over a lifetime. Conclusions: Most diabetes interventions evaluated by CUAs are recommended by practice guidelines and may provide good value for money. Our results indicate that patients with diabetes and the health care system could potentially benefit from shifting to the greater use of high-value services.

Authors: Fengler, MR; Hin, LY
Author Full Names: Fengler, Matthias R.; Hin, Lin-Yee
Article Title: Semi-nonparametric estimation of the call-option price surface under strike and time-to-expiry no-arbitrage constraints
Author Keywords: B-splines; No-arbitrage constraints; Option pricing function; Semi-nonparametric estimation; Shape-constrained regression; State-price density
Keywords Plus: STOCHASTIC VOLATILITY; ASYMPTOTIC NORMALITY; REGRESSION SPLINES; DENSITY-ESTIMATION; SMOOTHING SPLINES; LOCAL ASYMPTOTICS; LEAST-SQUARES; RISK-AVERSION; B-SPLINES; CONVEX
Abstract: We suggest a semi-nonparametric estimator for the call-option price surface. The estimator is a bivariate tensor-product B-spline. To enforce no-arbitrage constraints across strikes and expiry dates, we establish sufficient no-arbitrage conditions on the control net of the B-spline surface. The conditions are linear and therefore allow for an implementation of the estimator by means of standard quadratic programming techniques. The consistency of the estimator is proved. By means of simulations, we explore the statistical efficiency benefits that are associated with estimating option price surfaces and state-price densities under the full set of no-arbitrage constraints. We estimate a call-option price surface, families of first-order strike derivatives, and state-price densities for S&P 500 option data. (C) 2014 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Article Title: Probing Auditing Firms Performance Using a New DEMATEL Method Based on the Balanced Scorecard Approach
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2ND INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON FINANCE AND ECONOMICS 2015
Conference Title: 2nd International Conference on Finance and Economics (ICFE)
Conference Location: Ton Duc Thang Univ, Ho Chi Minh City, VIETNAM

Author Keywords: Balanced Scorecard (BSC); Audit Firm; Financial Performance; DEMATEL
Keywords Plus: MODEL
Abstract: Audit firms are a professional service organization rendering services to companies by professional auditors. In order to find ways to ensure that the model more accurately reflects the interdependence and feedback problems related to auditing firms performance evaluation factors, a DEMATEL model is developed. The goal is to establish an evaluation and relationship model of audit firm's performance that is based on the BSC model. Based on the analysis of expert interviews, it is suggested that audit firms performance improvement should be made in the following order: Learning and growth (A) Finance (D)_Client (C)_Audit firm's internal processes (B).

Authors: Chen, XF
Author Full Names: Chen Xiang-fen
Article Title: Measurement of Foreign Capital Utilization Efficiency of Suzhou Based on Malmquist Index
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: dynamic analysis; foreign capital utilization efficiency; Malmquist index
Abstract: Foreign direct investment has great significance to the economy. The economy of Suzhou is developed. And foreign capital plays a very important role for Suzhou's economic development. The higher the foreign capital utilization efficiency is, the bigger the contribution of foreign direct investment to economic development is. Therefore, it is of significance to analyze the efficiency of utilization of foreign investment in Suzhou. In this paper we analyzed the positive role of foreign capital utilization in Suzhou, and discussed the status of foreign capital utilization. Using DEA model and Malmquist index, we estimated the dynamic changes of the foreign capital utilization efficiency of Suzhou in recent years, and made a detailed analysis of the results. In the end, we give some advice to the foreign capital utilization.

Authors: Dokulilova, T; Gersl, M; Sotnar, M
Book Editors: Polak, O; Cerkal, R; Belcredi, NB
Author Full Names: Dokulilova, Tereza; Gersl, Milan; Sotnar, Martin
Article Title: OPERATING DIAGNOSTICS OF BIOGAS PLANTS
Conference Title: 22nd International PhD Students Conference
Conference Location: Mendel Univ, Fac Agron, Brno, CZECH REPUBLIC
Author Keywords: anaerobic fermentation; biogas; redox potential; pH; dry matter; total organic carbon
Abstract: This research deals with characteristics of processed organic material and its changes during anaerobic fermentation. Laboratory testing of anaerobic fermentation was performed in the Nationwide reference laboratory of biogas transformation at the Mendel University in Brno. The test took 26 days. During this period the composition and quantity of the biogas, conductivity, redox potential, pH, dry matter and total organic carbon in the processed material has been monitored. Determination of dry matter and total organic carbon proved to be unsuitable operating parameters for the diagnosis of biogas plants due to complicated sampling. The quantity of generated biogas, content methane in the biogas, conductivity, redox potential and pH of processed material are parameters which could provide descriptive information about process of anaerobic digestion and which can be useful for operational diagnostics of biogas plants. These parameters are closely related. For example development of redox potential correlates directly with the methane content in the biogas. And change of pH is in inverse proportion to development of redox potential. The conductivity during anaerobic fermentation gradually rose while the pH decreased. On the other hand determination of dry matter and total organic carbon proved to be unsuitable operating parameters for the diagnosis of biogas plants due to complicated sampling.

Authors: Fu, LP; Song, JS; Shao, TP
Book Editors: Qi, E; Shen, J; Dou, R
Author Full Names: Fu, Li-ping; Song, Jun-sheng; Shao, Tian-pin
Article Title: Macro Management Innovation, Institution Environment and Enterprise's Internal Capacity-A Case Study on Cultural Enterprises in Tianjin
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 21ST INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON INDUSTRIAL ENGINEERING AND ENGINEERING MANAGEMENT 2014
Conference Title: 21st International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management 2014 (IEEM)
Conference Sponsor: CMES, Chinese Ind Engn Inst,Beijing Inst Technol,Tianjin Univ Sci & Technol
Author Keywords: Cultural enterprises; factor analysis; structural equation model (SEM)
Abstract: Based on structural equation model (SEM), this article conducts an empirical study on the influence factors of enterprise's internal capacity using the survey data of 213 cultural enterprises in Tianjin. The results show that: macro management innovation (which consists of two parts: industrial policy and financial policy) as well as institution environment are proved to be the two main influence factors. Internal capacity relates significantly and positively with institution environment and industrial policy, while the active effects of industrial policy in Tianjin cannot reach the expected level. And the importance of financial policy hasn't been reflected. On this basis, this article puts forward policy suggestions for the development of cultural enterprises in Tianjin. For example, powerful legal system and policy system support should be set up especially financial policies and investment policies to create a sound micro environment for sustainable development.

Authors: Hong, J
Author Full Names: Hong Jie
Article Title: The Trade Creation Effect of WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement on China's Import and Export: Based on Gravity Model and Transnational Panel Data
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: WTO trade facilitation agreement; import and export; trade creation effect; gravity model
Abstract: WTO trade facilitation agreement, as the only multilateral agreement of the Doha round so far, is reached in early 2015. This agreement plays a positive role in promoting China's trade as China is in New. Normalcy and the present trade facilitation level is not high. Based on theoretical analysis on the agreement's trade creation effects towards China's trade, this paper establishes improved total trade amount, import and export gravity models to make empirical study on panel data of 40 WTO members, covering over 85% of China's trade amount. Then a forecast of China's trade amount is made using the regression results. The study shows: If trading partners' GDP increases by 1%, China's total trade amount and export will increase by 0.587% and 1.378% respectively. If China's trade facilitation gets improved by1%, China's total trade amount, import and export will increase by 4.602%, 4.977% and 3.069% respectively. If other conditions remain unchanged and the agreement is implemented from 2016, in 2020 China's trade amount will be benefited by an additional 30.79%'s growth. The improvement of trade facilitation imposed by Agreement can not only produce trade creation effect by reducing trade costs and promoting economic development, but also impose reform to China's port, custom and trade system, which will bring new reform bonus to China.

Authors: Hu, X; Hu, AA; Dai, WH; Zhu, WX
Author Full Names: Hu Xuan; Hu An-an; Dai Wei-hui; Zhu Wei-xiang
Article Title: Construction and Measurement of Artificial Psychological Emotion Model for Consumers' Online Shopping Behaviors
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: online marketing; emotional experience; artificial psychology emotion model; consumer behavior
Keywords Plus: ELECTRONIC COMMERCE; INTERNET; ACCEPTANCE; RISK
Abstract: With the continuous technical innovation for Internet in recent years, online shopping has been an important part of life for people. The traditional offline consumer spending habits are gradhally shifted to the online context. In contrast with the traditional idea that the emotional psychology is the output at end of the shopping process, more theoretical studies agree that emotional psychology should be played as important input which would demonstrate the final shopping decision-making. A good online marketing strategy should be developed to focus on consumer's emotional psychology and bring pleasurable experience. This study explores the relationship between emotions and online marketing strategies on the KDR (prior-Knowledge, existed-Data, further-Response) hybrid modeling framework. We propose an artificial psychology emotion model collaborating emotional experiences with rational cognitive factors affecting consumer's online shopping behavior building upon previous research, and create a set of testing process to capture and measure both shopping behavior and emotional experience data of respondents. The construction and measurement of our model provide a framework for the future research of online marketing strategy and practice.

Authors: Lai, WH
Book Editors: Pham, TML; Soukup, J; Phan, D; Phung, MT
Author Full Names: Lai, Wen-Hsiang
Article Title: Industrial Service Flexibility versus Regional Network Collaboration
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2ND INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON FINANCE AND ECONOMICS 2015
Conference Title: 2nd International Conference on Finance and Economics (ICFE)
Conference Location: Ton Duc Thang Univ, Ho Chi Minh City, VIETNAM
Conference Sponsor: Corvinus Univ Budapest,Taylors Univ,Nanhua Univ,Univ Econ,Asian Inst Technol,Vysoka Skola Ekonomicka
Author Keywords: Industry Service Flexibility (ISF); Regional Network Collaboration (RNC); Taiwan Machinery Industry (TMI); Industry Cluster
Keywords Plus: MANUFACTURING FLEXIBILITY; CLUSTER-ANALYSIS; COMPETITION; FRAMEWORK
Abstract: Industry clusters link firms in specific industries in a geographical area and comprise vertical and horizontal business supply chain partners. Industrial service flexibility (ISF) is strongly related to goal-driven innovation within clusters in a regional network. The regional network collaboration (RNC) facilitates commerce and service relationships by coordinating production and merchandise flows. This study reviews relevant academic literature and divides the dimensions of ISF efficiency into internal ISF and external ISF. This study further explores the influential factors of RNC as dimensions of geography, resource and network. This study finds that the distance proximity and company scale are not significant to the efficiency of internal and external ISFs. Talent resource and information network provide significant linkages to the efficiency of internal and external ISFs. Finally, this study finds that to improve the efficiency of ISF, network information is important to the internal ISF, and network interaction is an indispensable element in external ISF.

Authors: Leonova, T; Malanicheva, N; Khasuntsev, I; Bochkovskiy, P
Author Full Names: Leonova, Tatiana; Malanicheva, Natalia; Khasuntsev, Igor; Bochkovskiy, Pavel
Article Title: Analysis of the International Trends of Research and Development Efficiency
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: correlational analysis; development indicators; patent triads; performance evaluation; science and technology; technological development
Abstract: The article presents the comparative and correlational analysis of the science and technological indicators of the leading and emerging countries. Modern science and technology systems of G7 and BRICS countries have gone through several changes through the last decade that include the development of infrastructure, new scientific and technological policies and regulatory frameworks. The presented analysis is based on comparison of retrospective trends of main science indicators since 2000. During this study several research methods have been applied, including system analysis, statistics and econometrical analysis. Several expert methods of the analysis were used to evaluate the level of research and development performance indicators. This article represents the fact that in the context of building an innovative economy basing on the achievements of science the BRICS countries made a breakthrough in the growth rate of researchers, that ensured the accelerated development of science and economy.

Authors: Li, Q; Wang, XC
Author Full Names: Li Qian; Wang Xiu-cun
Article Title: Development and Validation of the Norm of Reciprocity Scale in the Engagement Management Context
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: engagement management; norm of reciprocity; scale development; scale validation
Keywords Plus: CONSTRUCT-VALIDITY; TRUST; CONTRACT; MODEL
Abstract: Based on the reviewing the previous studies, we use the pre-investigation and large sample investigation, and develop the measurement items by conducting the interviews and content analysis. The principal component analysis rotated to varimax rotation was used to obtain evidence for the validity of the scale. The research findings show that there is three main dimensions, including Non-interpersonal resource norms(NIRN), Interpersonal resource norms(IRN) and Responsibility norms (RN). Considering the results obtained from the validity and reliability studies, it can be asserted that the norm of reciprocity scale can be used to determine managers' reciprocity views and awareness in the engagement management context. Given this broad array of evidence for its construct validity can employ this validated scale to investigate various forms for the engagement management context work settings.

Authors: Liu, CM; Wang, YQ
Author Full Names: Liu Cai-mei; Wang Yi-qin
Article Title: A Study on the Relation between Corporate Culture and Corporate Social Performance
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: corporate culture; corporate social performance; the strength of corporate culture; the consistency of corporate culture
Keywords Plus: RESPONSIBILITY; LINE
Abstract: Corporate culture is an important aspect to be considered by organizations in order to develop some competitive advantages and enhance corporate social performance. The main purpose of this research is to examine and prove the influence of corporate culture on corporate social performance. Thus this paper constructs the model between them, with the moderator of corporate culture strength and the consistency of corporate culture. Based on the survey data, results show that: corporate culture has a positive effect on corporate social performance. The strength and consistency of corporate culture can positively and partly moderate the relationship between them. According to the results, this study offers suggestions for organization management on corporate culture construction and good corporate social responsibility acquisition.

Authors: Markopoulos, G; Mikros, G; Iliadi, A; Liontos, M
Author Full Names: Markopoulos, George; Mikros, George; Iliadi, Anastasia; Liontos, Michalis
Article Title: Sentiment Analysis of Hotel Reviews in Greek: A Comparison of Unigram Features
Source Title: CULTURAL TOURISM IN A DIGITAL ERA
Book Series Title: Springer Proceedings in Business and Economics
Conference Title: 1st IACuDiT International Conference on Cultural Tourism in a Digital Era
Conference Sponsor: Int Assoc Cultural & Digital Tourism
Author Keywords: Sentiment analysis; Text mining; Information retrieval; Machine learning; Natural language processing
Abstract: Web 2.0 has become a very useful information resource nowadays, as people are strongly inclined to express online their opinion in social media, blogs and review sites. Sentiment analysis aims at classifying documents as positive or negative according to their overall expressed sentiment. In this paper, we create a sentiment classifier applying Support Vector Machines on hotel reviews written in Modern Greek. Using a unigram language model, we compare two different methodologies and the emerging results look very promising.

Authors: Necadová, M
Book Editors: Pham, TML; Soukup, J; Phan, D; Phung, MT
Author Full Names: Necadova, Marta
Article Title: The Arguable Concept of National Competitiveness - Methodology of WEF and Results of Selected Countries in Global Competitiveness Report
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2ND INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON FINANCE AND ECONOMICS 2015
Conference Title: 2nd International Conference on Finance and Economics (ICFE)
Conference Location: Ton Duc Thang Univ, Ho Chi Minh City, VIETNAM
Conference Sponsor: Corvinus Univ Budapest,Taylors Univ,Nanhua Univ,Univ Econ,Asian Inst Technol,Vysoka Skola Ekonomicka
Author Keywords: National (coUntry) Competitiveness; Global Competitiveness Report; Global Competitiveness Index
Abstract: The first objective of this paper is to explain why the concept of national competitiveness is controversial and what factors and connections should be taken into account when the national level competitiveness is considered. The objective view on the term national competitiveness must respect the increasing fragmentation of production across borders and the increasing use of foreign inputs. Traditional measures of national competitiveness can no longer be maintained. The second objective is to describe and critically evaluate the methodology that was used by World Economic Forum for construction of the Global Competitiveness Index. The critical description of the methodology for measurement of competitiveness is accompanied by the analysis of selected countries. The group of countries consists of three EU biggest economies (Germany, France and United Kingdom), BRICS countries (Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa), key Far East economies (Republic of Korea and Japan) and Australia. With regard to the focus of this conference, the Czech Republic and Vietnam are also included in the group of analysed countries. The results of Global Competitiveness Report and country rankings according to Global Competitiveness Index are used for analysis of national competitiveness.

Authors: Ouyang, YL; Zhang, MX; Han, L; Lu, Y
Author Full Names: Ouyang Yong-liu; Zhang Meng-xiang; Han Lu; Lu Yi
Article Title: Multiproject Time-cost Trade-off Scheduling Problem for Large-scale Construction Systems under Fuzzy Uncertainty
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: construction project; fuzzy uncertainty; genetic algorithm; multiproject time -cost trade-off scheduling problem
Keywords Plus: MULTICRITERIA DECISION-MAKING; GENETIC ALGORITHM; OPTIMIZATION
Abstract: This paper presents a multiproject time-cost trade-off scheduling problem (mPTCTSP) for large-scale construction systems with multiple modes under fuzzy environment. A multiobjective decision making model is established in the total project duration which is regarded as a fuzzy variable. The fuzzy numbers in the model are defuzzified by using an expected value operator with an optimistic-pessimistic index. The multiobjective fuzzy optimization model designed in this study aims to simultaneously minimize project duration and delaying punishment cost. Furthermore, the hybrid genetic algorithm with fuzzy logic controller (flc-hGA) is developed to find feasible solutions. Finally, the Jinping-II Hydroelectric Project is used as a practical example to demonstrate the practicality and efficiency of the model.

Authors: Pan, F; Xi, B; Wang, L
Author Full Names: Pan Feng; Xi Bao; Wang Lin
Article Title: Principal-Agent Model of Local Government Environmental Regulation Implementation under Chinese Style Decentralization
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: environmental regulation; local government; multi-task principal-agent
Keywords Plus: IMPERFECT INFORMATION
Abstract: There is the principal-agent relationship between local government and central government in environmental regulation implementation. The optimal incentive contract and its influencing factors are given through establishing multi-task principal-agent model of local government and central government in China. The impact on optimal incentive contract from related factors of local government environmental regulation is analyzed based on the multi-task principal-agent model. The results show that the optimal incentive contract is affected by the degree of central government's attention on economic growth and environmental quality, the economic development ability of local government, the variance of pollution reductions, the risk preference of local government, the implementing cost of environmental regulation and the economic cost of environmental regulation. The central government should establish and adjust optimal incentive contract based on the degree 'of central government's attention on different task and the attribute of local government.

Authors: Peiris, MU; Tsomocos, DP
Author Full Names: Peiris, M. Udara; Tsomocos, Dimitrios P.
Article Title: International monetary equilibrium with default
Author Keywords: International finance; Monetary policy; Default; Equilibrium analysis
Keywords Plus: GENERAL EQUILIBRIUM; TRADING ECONOMY; FIAT MONEY; MODEL; DETERMINACY; BANKRUPTCY; PRICES; RATES
Abstract: We present an integrated framework for the study of the international financial economy with trade, fiat money, monetary and fiscal policy, endogenous default and regulation. Money is introduced via a cash-in-advance requirement and real trade is endogenous. The standard international finance pricing results obtain. Market incompleteness and positive default in equilibrium allow for the study of the transmission of default through the international financial markets and imply a positive role for policy. Finally, we present an example where, due to the trade-off between the non-pecuniary cost of default and the resulting allocation, a Pareto improvement occurs following an increase in interest rates. Authors: Soukup, J
Book Editors: Pham, TML; Soukup, J; Phan, D; Phung, MT
Author Full Names: Soukup, Jindrich
Article Title: The Competitiveness Based on Innovation: EU, BRICS and Vietnam
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2ND INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON FINANCE AND ECONOMICS 2015
Conference Title: 2nd International Conference on Finance and Economics (ICFE)
Conference Location: Ton Duc Thang Univ, Ho Chi Minh City, VIETNAM
Conference Sponsor: Corvinus Univ Budapest,Taylors Univ,Nanhua Univ,Univ Econ,Asian Inst Technol,Vysoka Skola Ekonomicka
Author Keywords: Knowledge Economy; Innovation; Competitiveness
Keywords Plus: GROWTH
Abstract: The first part of the paper explains how models of the economic growth have gradually changed views on the role of technological progress and innovations from the 40s of the 20th century to the present. The second part is devoted to the analysis of the category knowledge economy. The third section describes the methodology that was used for the construction of the World Innovation Index which was constructed at the Faculty of Business Administration, University of Economics, Prague. The fourth and fifth parts of the paper assess - using the World Innovation Index - the competitiveness based on innovation for the group of selected countries. The set of countries implements three EU biggest economies (Germany, France and United Kingdom), all BRICS countries (e.g. Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa), key Far East economies (Republic of Korea and Japan) together with Australia. With regard to the focus of this conference, the Czech Republic and Vietnam are also implemented into the set of the analysed countries.

Authors: Sun, YY; Liu, XL
Author Full Names: Sun Yan-yong; Liu Xue-lin
Article Title: The Study on Implementation Methodologies of CGTR Key Technologies
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering

Author Keywords: CGTR; finance management; methodology study; organization structure; project management
Keywords Plus: ORGANIZATION STRUCTURE; INNOVATION; PERFORMANCE; NETWORKS; SUPPORT
Abstract: This paper is the embodiment of CGTR project management. Based on the advantages of ESA standard management in complex system engineering projects and the management practice of China institutes in defence system engineering projects, a new project management method of complex electronic system engineering was proposed, with specific approaches to promote communication and coordination capability, to increase efficiency, to improve flow and optimize management effect in organization, technology, finance and risk management. Based on this study, we can integrate the project management theory and practice, improve management capability, and realize the final project goals.

Authors: Tang, T
Book Editors: Qi, E; Shen, J; Dou, R
Author Full Names: Tang, Tang
Article Title: Research on the Risk Identification for the International Engineering Contracting EPC Projects
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 21ST INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON INDUSTRIAL ENGINEERING AND ENGINEERING MANAGEMENT 2014
Conference Title: 21st International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Engineering Management 2014 (IEEM)
Conference Sponsor: CMES, Chinese Ind Engn Inst,Beijing Inst Technol,Tianjin Univ Sci & Technol
Author Keywords: Engineering procurement construction (EPC); interpretative structural modeling (ISM); risk identification
Keywords Plus: MANAGING RISK
Abstract: The International Engineering Contracting EPC projects have the characteristics of high risk, intense complexity and numbers of uncertainties. Thus, as the basis of the risk assessment, risk response and risk control, risk identification can achieve the goal of systematically, dynamically identify, classify, and analyze the risk, thereby contributing to risk aversion and reducing the risk of loss. In this paper, through the literature review and survey analysis, filter out the risks which has the largerprobability of occurrence, the higher-degree of harm and the weaker-management-capacity, establishing the list of risk factors of international project contracting EPC project. Subsequently, this paper suggests the use of interpretative structural modeling (ISM) to prepare a hierarchical structure as well as the interrelationships of these risks, exploring the mechanism of interaction between the risks with the steps as followed, establishing the adjacency matrix and reachability matrix according to the bivariate correlation between the risk factors to, and dividing into elements of level, so as to provide theoretical and practical instruction as well as to offer the EPC contractor additional evidence on the decision-making.

Authors: Tian, W; Huang, H
Author Full Names: Tian Wen; Huang Hui
Article Title: Executive Power, Monetary Compensation and Perks: Empirical Evidences from Chinese Listed Companies
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: monetary compensation; perks; power of executives; compensation reform
Abstract: Executive compensation is an important topic of Chinese enterprises reform. Based on the panel data of 1511 non-financial listed companies in China from 2009 to 2013, We examine interaction among executive power, monetary compensation and perks, Subsequently, we find that executive power is positive associated with monetary compensation while negatively associated with perks. Besides, monetary compensation has alternative relationship with perks, however, the greater executive power and the more pronounced the relationship. These empirical results are very robust, which would help consummate salary system reform and manager incentives mechanism, specifically, solve some problems of the executive compensation contract effectiveness in the listed companies.

Authors: Pham, TT
Book Editors: Pham, TML; Soukup, J; Phan, D; Phung, MT
Author Full Names: Tien Thanh Pham
Article Title: Impact of Microcredit on Living Standards - The Case of Vietnamese Rural Households
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2ND INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON FINANCE AND ECONOMICS 2015
Conference Title: 2nd International Conference on Finance and Economics (ICFE)
Conference Location: Ton Duc Thang Univ, Ho Chi Minh City, VIETNAM
Conference Sponsor: Corvinus Univ Budapest,Taylors Univ,Nanhua Univ,Univ Econ,Asian Inst Technol,Vysoka Skola Ekonomicka
Author Keywords: Impact Evaluation; Microcredit; PSM; Vietnam; Welfare
Keywords Plus: PROPENSITY SCORE; CREDIT PROGRAMS; POVERTY; MICROFINANCE; POOR
Abstract: This paper examines the impact of microcredit on the living standard of the rural households in Vietnam. In order to assess this impact, this study applied propensity score matching (PSM) method. The findings show that microcredit program improves living standard of the rural households regarding higher income and expenditure per capita per month, education expenditure and total of accommodation, electricity and garbage expense. However, the results find no evidence for the relationship between microcredit and medical expenditure. Also in this study, it indicates that microcredit programs may not serve the poor households in the rural Vietnam.

Authors: Wang, JH; Sun, JH; Zhi, YR
Author Full Names: Wang Jing-hong; Sun Jin-hua; Zhi You-ran
Article Title: An Optimization Based Route-Travelling-Efficiency Risk Assessment Framework for Large-scale Evacuation Routing under Disaster Environments
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: routing plan; disaster spread; route failure; RTE risk; utility function
Keywords Plus: EXPECTED-UTILITY-THEORY; MODEL; CHOICE; DECISION
Abstract: One of the most important goals of large-scale evacuation plans under disasters is to ensure that the population; in hazardous areas can be transferred quickly to safe destinations through rational evacuation planning which can achieve maximum efficiency across the entire evacuation system. Numerous literatures have been reported on the evacuation routing plans, but few papers have focused on the risk of such plans caused by the dynamic development of disasters. In this paper, using some reasonable assumptions as to disaster spread and damage, we applied the dynamic network flow method to establish a multi-source-multi-destination (MSMD) large-scale evacuation model, based on which the influence of evacuation priority and the general pattern of disaster spread were comprehensively considered. Using a kind of dynamic parallel processing heuristic algorithm, the optimal evacuation planning was solved and compared to previous work. As a result of these analyses, we further proposed a concept of route travelling efficiency risk (RTE risk), and established its quantitative assessment framework based on the utility theory. The value of RTE risk calculated from the framework of each road link at a different moment after the disaster occurs can effectively reflect the dynamic change in appropriateness for travelling of the evacuation road network in a disaster environment, considering both efficiency and risk.

Authors: Wang, JY; Choudhry, T
Book Editors: Pham, TML; Soukup, J; Phan, D; Phung, MT
Author Full Names: Wang, Jo-Yu; Choudhry, Taufiq
Article Title: Value-at-Risk Based on Extreme Value Theory: Evidence from Asian and Latin American Emerging Markets
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2ND INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON FINANCE AND ECONOMICS 2015
Conference Title: 2nd International Conference on Finance and Economics (ICFE)
Conference Location: Ton Duc Thang Univ, Ho Chi Minh City, VIETNAM
Conference Sponsor: Corvinus Univ Budapest,Taylors Univ,Nanhua Univ,Univ Econ,Asian Inst Technol,Vysoka Skola Ekonomicka
Author Keywords: Value at Risk; Extreme Value Theory; GARCH
Keywords Plus: FREQUENCY-DISTRIBUTION; HISTORICAL SIMULATION; OIL PRICE; MODELS; PERFORMANCE; PORTFOLIOS
Abstract: This study applies extreme value theory (EVT) to fit the generalized extreme value (GEV) distribution of index returns, and the GEV distribution is applied to measure daily market risk (i.e. Value at Risk; VaR) of six Asian and four Latin American emerging markets. We emphasize two aspects of VaR model evaluation: coverage tests and the quality of forecasted VaR pattern. Apart from Kupiec (1995) and Christoffersen's (1998) methods, three quality measures are proposed to evaluate different VaR models. The GEV results are compared with three other conventional VaR approaches; the GARCH model, RiskMetrics, and historical simulation. The coverage tests showed that historical simulation with 250 historical data and the GEV model based on a 5-day block statistically provide equivalent significance in daily VaR forecasting, but the violation rate of the GEV model is more accurate than the other models. In the quality tests, the GEV model offers the smallest variation and satisfactory conservativeness in the VaR pattern.

Authors: Xu, JH; Zou, XQ
Author Full Names: Xu Ji-hui; Zou Xing-qi
Article Title: Modeling and Empirical Analysis of Schedule Bayesian Network on Aircraft Development
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: aircraft development; schedule risk; schedule Bayesian network; risk modeling; Matlab
Abstract: Aiming at the problem of behind schedule in aircraft development, the paper put forwards the Schedule Bayesian Network (SBN) that is to optimize the traditional Bias based on the technology of PERT. Tracking and investigating a unit of aircraft development, the paper establishes the Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) of schedule risk and constructs the model of SBN. Taking a unit of wing development as an example, the paper simulates the development project and infers the most likely and timely completed time. The model of SBN established in the paper not only infers the probability on time, can also reason the delayed factor and its probability. The results show that the model of SBN provides theoretical and practical basis for targeted controlling schedule risk.

Authors: Yan, HH
Author Full Names: Yan Hui-hui
Article Title: The Knowledge Mapping of China's Land-lost Peasants Research-Bibliometric Analysis Based on Citespace
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: land-lost peasant; citespaIII; knowledge groups; evolution routes
Abstract: Research about land-lost peasant has aroused the widespread attention of scholars. Land-lost peasants' type, number, spatial distribution land urbanization process has caused China's scholars' attention and theory's innovation. In recent years, alongside enhancements to the basic theory and improvement in research systems, land-lost peasants' research has formed different research centers and build new frontiers. This paper synthesizes information visualization methods, bibliometric methods and data mining algorithms and visualizei the development process and structural relationship of land-lost peasant research by using the information visualization analysis software-Citespaceill. The research uses data from 489 articles about land-lost peasant in the CSSCI database during 2003-2014. With the co-citation network analysis and burst detection, the paper analyzes the China's research status of the land-lost peasant research field. The results reveal that China's land-lost peasants' research can be divided into four phases, the theme of each stage has a relatively concentrated. (1)The early stage of research: Why the interests of land-lost peasants are damaged and how. Combining the reasons of peasants' lands lost and interests damaged, directly to the cause of land-lost peasants to explain the peasants' interests damaged, then have the point of view-the reasons causing peasants' land lost also cause the peasants' interests damaged. (2)The middle stage of the research: the design and practice of land-lost peasants resettlement mode and guarantee mechanism. (3)The late stage of research: research on the land-lost peasants' urbanization. If the land-lost peasants can not enjoy the same living conditions and development space after they going into city, the experience of urbanization was fail. (4)The new stage of research: from survive to development. Compensation and security is not enough, land-lost peasants' sustainable long-term survival strategy is fundamental to solve the problem.

Authors: Yang, X; Wang, SS; Huang, JM
Author Full Names: Yang Xi; Wang Su-sheng; Huang Jie-min
Article Title: The Heterogeneous Effect of Venture Capital on Entrepreneurial Firms' Performance
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: venture capital; heterogeneous effect; performance; ChiNext board
Keywords Plus: PRIVATE; CERTIFICATION; INVESTMENTS; PERSPECTIVE; GOVERNANCE; SELECTION; CHINA; IPOS
Abstract: In the past two decades, venture capital has played quite an important role in promoting the growth of small and medium enterprises, which has drawn great attention from the academic circles. While there is a large amount of financial literature on the contribution of venture capital to the performance of entrepreneurial firms, there are relatively few empirical studies that identify VC firms' heterogeneous effect on the performance of entrepreneurial firms. This article selects the Chinese listed companies dated from 2009 to 2012 on the ChiNext board as the research samples and explore whether VC-backed firms in China generally outperform their non VC-backed counterparts, and if so, further exploring the effect of VC firms' heterogeneity on entrepreneurial firms' performance, with the focus on the factors of VC firms' capital background, reputation and investment approaches. Our analysis shows that VC-backed firms outperform non VC-backed firms in the aspect of growth ability. Furthermore, we find different types of VC and investment approaches also affect the performance of the venture firms differently. Ventures backed by foreign VC firms perform better in the profitability, compared to those backed by domestic VC firms. Firms backed by syndicated investment perform better in the profitability, compared to those backed by non-syndicated investment. Firms backed by staged VC investment perform better in the growth ability, compared to those backed by VC investment with non-staged financing approach. Thus we get the conclusion that foreign VC firms, VC firms with syndicated investment approach or staged financing approach can add more value to the investee companies.

Abstract: Recent years, government is actively promoting innovation in technology defense industry by breaking the closed system and introducing the market competition mechanism, hoping to make full use of the whole social resources and improve weaponry and equipment production capacity. To seek for survival and development, aviation manufacturing enterprises need to adjust to the new environment. Authors: Zhang, YM; Jin, H; Li, YY
Author Full Names: Zhang Yu-miao; Jin Hao; Li Yuan-yuan
Article Title: A Study on the Relationship between Financial Resource Allocation and Economic Growth Based on Hebei Province
Source Title: 2015 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT SCIENCE & ENGINEERING - 22ND ANNUAL CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, VOLS I AND II
Book Series Title: International Conference on Management Science and Engineering-Annual Conference Proceedings
Conference Title: 22nd International Conference on Management Science and Engineering
Conference Sponsor: Dubai Int Acad City,Sch Management, Harbin Inst Technol,IEEE Technol Management Council,Natl Nat Sci Fdn China,Harbin Inst Technol
Author Keywords: financial resource allocation; economic growth; cointegration test; Granger causality test
Abstract: The relationship between financial resource allocation which as the main manifestation of medium measure finance and economic growth has been one of the hot issues of economics research. This paper, based on the relevant data from 2000 to 2013, builds the four indexes which are the financial interrelation ratio (FIR), the efficiency of financial resource allocation (SLR), the financial market development (FMD) and the financial openness (FO) to measure the financial resource allocation level, and uses cointegration test and Granger causality test to analyze the relationship between financial resource allocation and economic growth of Hebei province. The results show that there exists a long-term stable equilibrium relationship between financial resource allocation and economic growth, and FIR, FMD and FO are one-way Granger cause of economic growth, other causality not formed. According to the empirical results, this paper gives some suggestions on optimizing the allocation of financial resources and promoting economic growth of Hebei province.

Authors: González, P; Macho-Stadler, I; Pérez-Castrillo, D
Author Full Names: Gonzalez, Paula; Macho-Stadler, Ines; Perez-Castrillo, David
Article Title: Private versus social incentives for pharmaceutical innovation
Conference Title: 16th European Health Economics Workshop
Author Keywords: Pharmaceuticals; R&D activities; Me-too drugs; Breakthrough drugs; Innovation
Keywords Plus: RESEARCH-AND-DEVELOPMENT; INDUSTRY
Abstract: We provide a theoretical framework to contribute to the current debate regarding-the tendency of pharmaceutical companies to direct their R&D toward marketing products that are follow-on drugs of already existing drugs, rather than toward the development of breakthrough drugs. We construct a model with a population of patients who can be treated with drugs that are horizontally and vertically differentiated. In addition to a pioneering drug, a new drug can be marketed as the result of an innovative process. We analyze physician prescription choices and the optimal pricing decision of an innovative firm. We also characterize the incentives of the innovative firm to conduct R&D activities, disentangling the quest for breakthrough drugs from the firm effort to develop follow-on drugs. Our results offer theoretical support for the conventional wisdom that pharmaceutical firms devote too many resources to conducting R&D activities that lead to incremental innovations. Authors: Rahman, M; Norton, EC; Grabowski, DC
Author Full Names: Rahman, Momotazur; Norton, Edward C.; Grabowski, David C.
Article Title: Do hospital-owned skilled nursing facilities provide better post-acute care quality?
Author Keywords: Hospital-based; Skilled nursing facilities; Medicare; Care utilization trajectory; Instrumental variable; Post-acute care
Keywords Plus: LONG-TERM-CARE; RESIDENT ASSESSMENT INSTRUMENT; MEDICARE PROSPECTIVE-PAYMENT; RESOURCE UTILIZATION GROUPS; MINIMUM DATA SET; OF-CARE; HOME; MDS; REHOSPITALIZATIONS; MORTALITY
Abstract: As hospitals are increasingly held accountable for patients' post-discharge outcomes under new payment models, hospitals may choose to acquire skilled nursing facilities (SNFs) to better manage these outcomes. This raises the question of whether patients discharged to hospital-based SNFs have better outcomes. In unadjusted comparisons, hospital-based SNF patients have much lower Medicare utilization in the 180 days following discharge relative to freestanding SNF patients. We solved the problem of differential selection into hospital-based and freestanding SNFs by using differential distance from home to the nearest hospital with a SNF relative to the distance from home to the nearest hospital without a SNF as an instrument. We found that hospital-based SNF patients spent roughly 5 more days in the community and 6 fewer days in the SNF in the 180 days following,their original hospital discharge with no significant effect on mortality or hospital readmission. Authors: Lan, W; Zhong, PS; Li, RZ; Wang, HS; Tsai, CL
Author Full Names: Lan, Wei; Zhong, Ping-Shou; Li, Runze; Wang, Hansheng; Tsai, Chih-Ling
Article Title: Testing a single regression coefficient in high dimensional linear models
Author Keywords: Correlated Predictors Screening; False discovery rate; High dimensional data; Single coefficient test
Keywords Plus: FALSE DISCOVERY RATES; VARIABLE SELECTION; LASSO; CONSISTENCY; DEPENDENCE; GRAPHS
Abstract: In linear regression models with high dimensional data, the classical z-test (or t-test) for testing the significance of each single regression coefficient is no longer applicable. This is mainly because the number of covariates exceeds the sample size. In this paper, we propose a simple and novel alternative by introducing the Correlated Predictors Screening (CPS) method to control for predictors that are highly correlated with the target covariate. Accordingly, the classical ordinary least squares approach can be employed to estimate the regression coefficient associated with the target covariate. In addition, we demonstrate that the resulting estimator is consistent and asymptotically normal even if the random errors are heteroscedastic. This enables us to apply the z-test to assess the significance of each covariate. Based on the p-value obtained from testing the significance of each covariate, we further conduct multiple hypothesis testing by controlling the false discovery rate at the nominal level. Then, we show that the multiple hypothesis testing achieves consistent model selection. Simulation studies and empirical examples are presented to illustrate the finite sample performance and the usefulness of the proposed method, respectively. (C) 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Abstract: We apply local linear regression and sieve estimation technique to estimate functional coefficients and an unknown spatial weighting function, respectively, via a nonparametric GMM estimation method, where we allow both exogenous and endogenous spatial covariates. A consistency result is derived to support the method. Moreover, a two-step estimator is constructed for the functional coefficients, and under certain conditions, we show that this estimator can be oracle efficient in the sense that its limiting distribution is the same regardless of whether or not the spatial weights are known. Both simulated and real data examples are used to illustrate our theory. (C) 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Tarbush, B
Author Full Names: Tarbush, Bassel
Article Title: Counterfactuals in agreeing to disagree type results
Keywords Plus: KNOWLEDGE
Abstract: Moses and Nachum (1990) identified conceptual flaws (later echoed by Samet, 2010) in Bacharach's (1985) generalization of Aumann's (1976) seminal agreeing to disagree result by demonstrating that the crucial assumptions of like-mindedness and the Sure-Thing Principle are not meaningfully expressible in standard partitional information structures. This paper presents a new agreement theorem couched in counterfactual information structures that resolves these conceptual flaws. The new version of the Sure Thing Principle introduced here, which accounts for beliefs at counterfactual states, is also shown to sit well with the intuition of the original version proposed by Savage (1972). Authors: Mühlbacher, AC; Juhnke, C; Beyer, AR; Garner, S
Author Full Names: Muehlbacher, Axel C.; Juhnke, Christin; Beyer, Andrea R.; Garner, Sarah
Article Title: Patient-Focused Benefit-Risk Analysis to Inform Regulatory Decisions: The European Union Perspective
Author Keywords: benefit-risk assessment; patient involvement; regulatory decision making
Keywords Plus: HEALTH TECHNOLOGY-ASSESSMENT; PUBLIC-PARTICIPATION; ANALYSIS MCDA; CARE; MEDICINES; PREFERENCES; OUTCOMES; HTA
Abstract: Regulatory decisions are often based on multiple clinical end points, but the perspectives used to judge the relative importance of those end points are predominantly those of expert decision makers rather than of the patient. However, there is a growing awareness that active patient and public participation can improve decision making, increase acceptance of decisions, and improve adherence to treatments. The assessment of risk versus benefit requires not only information on clinical outcomes but also value judgments about which outcomes are important and whether the potential benefits outweigh the harms. There are a number of mechanisms for capturing the input of patients, and regulatory bodies within the European Union are participating in several initiatives. These can include patients directly participating in the regulatory decision-making process or using information derived from patients in empirical studies as part of the evidence considered. One promising method that is being explored is the elicitation of patient preferences. Preferences, in this context, refer to the individual's evaluation of health outcomes and can be understood as statements regarding the relative desirability of a range of treatment options, treatment characteristics, and health states. Several methods for preference measurement have been proposed, and pilot studies have been undertaken to use patient preference information in regulatory decision making. This article describes how preferences are currently being considered in the benefit-risk assessment context, and shows how different methods of preference elicitation are used to support decision making within the European context.

Authors: Yadav, S
Author Full Names: Yadav, Sonal
Article Title: Selecting winners with partially honest jurors
Keywords Plus: NASH IMPLEMENTATION
Abstract: We consider the effect of partially honest jurors (along the lines of Dutta and Sen (2012)) in a model of juror decisions developed in Amoros (2013). We analyse the problem of choosing the w contestants who will win a competition within a group of n > w competitors. All jurors know who the w best contestants are. All the jurors commonly observe who the w best contestants are, but they may be biased (in favour of or against some contestants). We assume that some of these jurors are partially honest. A partially honest individual has a strict preference for revealing the true state over lying when truth-telling does not lead to a worse outcome (according to preferences in the true state) than that which obtains when lying. The socially optimal rule is to always select the w best contestants, in every possible state of the world. We first look at the many person implementation, when the jury consists of at least two partially honest jurors, whose identity is not known to the planner. We find that the socially optimal rule is Nash implementable if for each pair of contestants, there are two jurors who treat the pair in an unbiased manner and one of these jurors is partially honest. However it is not necessary for the planner to know the identity of the jurors who are fair over a given pair. The result shows that the presence of partially honest jurors expands the scope of implementation. We also analyse the problem, when there are only two jurors and consider cases both with and without the assumption of partial honesty. (C) 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
